PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional distrubances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological distrubances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) The Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the current intention of Telecom Australia to increase the International Particular Person Fee and introduce a charge on the Ring Back Price service will :
Substantially affect the ability of the manual assistance area of Telecom's operations to compete effectively with STD and ISD.
Such pricing discrimination in favour of direct dialling and away from operator assisted calls will affect the future viability of a personalised, reliable manual assistance service.
The ramifications of such a pricing policy will also ultimately affect the employment of thousands of Telephonists and Supervisors currently working in this area.
Contravene the spirit of the current Prices and Incomes Policy which Telecom as a public authority should be a party to.

We the undersigned believe that the provision of a personalised telephone service is an essential component in any Telecommunication system. Australia has a long history of service from the manual assistance area and we cannot now allow Telecom's pricing policies to endanger the continuation of this service.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will call on the Government to intervene to stop Telecom's proposed charges increase and so ensure the future viability of Australia's manual assistance telephone network.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Macedonian Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
(1) That the Macedonian language be used by Government Departments in multi- lingual publications.
(2) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language as a Higher School Certificate (HSC) subject in Secondary schools.
(3) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language in tertiary institutions and that a course be introduced at Monash University in the Department of Slavic Languages.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate action to implement the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Alcoholic Beverages
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) Noting that the 1982 National Budget includes increased taxes on beer and spirits, we draw attention to the fact that wines have a higher alcoholic content than beer and that wine consumption must be a significant factor in the mounting problems arising from the use of alcoholic beverages; we request that all alcoholic wines be taxed to a degree comparable to the taxes on other alcoholic beverages.
(2) Whereas non-alcoholic wines do not cause social problems we request that no tax on these drinks be imposed.
(3) That government imposts on all alcoholic beverages be adjusted annually so that the real price of the beverages remain constant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Podiatry Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembed. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of podiatry service for lower fixed income members of the community.

Podiatry is an essential health service especially in preventing greater dependency of older people. It would be much more cost effective to maintain the mobility of older people through adequate and effective services than to force them into premature institutional care.

The fees for repeated podiatry consultations to provide essential ongoing care are well beyond the means of pensioners. Considering that Department of Veterans ' Affairs pensioners are entitled to podiatry care, and this scheme is already operating successfully, we strongly urge that this service be extended to cover all pensioners.

We believe this could be best achieved through including podiatry along with the existing concessions on the Health Care Cards. This would enable a flexible system of care through private practice, community health or rehabilitation services. It would also be essential in negotiations with the Podiatry Association to ensure assistance would be available to the housebound and those in institutions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of three Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefor pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change'.

PETITION.TITLE: Mackay District Assistance Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Mackay respecfully showeth:

reduce job opportunities in the area.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecommunications Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of Swan Hill and district in the State of Victoria respectfully show:

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Victoria respectfully show:
Last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
Alcohol is a factor in 50 per cent of road deaths;
Alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
Alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the citizens of the City of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holden's, respectfully show:
1. That the management of General Motors-Holden's has failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Prime Minister. Why did the Prime Minister mislead the House in claiming that Mr David Combe and his solicitor had a full chance to view the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation tapes and transcripts, or is it Mr Combe who is not telling the truth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker I assure the House that this is not a Dorothy Dixer. I would remind the House of the answer I gave on this matter on 12 May last. I ask all honourable members, including particularly the honourable member who directed this question to me, to listen carefully and understand what I said to the House . I hope that when he has heard what I have to say he will retract any imputation in his question. This is what I said to the House:

ANSWER.PARA: We proceeded to do something which has never before been done in the country in terms of protecting the rights of an individual affected by a decision of Government in a security area. We got Mr Combe, with his lawyer, to have discussions with the Attorney-General. May I say that this was done with the full concurrence, and indeed the involvement, of the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Mr Combe prepared his statement of his knowledge of his past associations and what he had been doing. Mr Combe was given then the opportunity-I repeat that this was done with the full involvement of the Director-General of Security; so let there be no spurious suggestions that the Government was acting in a way contrary to the proper security interests of this country-with his lawyer, of examining the basis of the Government's decision.

As a result of being given that opportunity, which I repeat to the House had never before been given to anyone in this sort of situation but was done with the full co-operation of the Director-General of ASIO who, for part of the time was present, Mr Combe in those circumstances of knowing the basis of the Government's decision associated himself with the statement put by me to this House that he understood and accepted the decision of the Government. Mr Speaker , I suggest to you and to all honourable members of this House who are capable of looking at this in terms of the twin issues of the security of this country and the rights of the individual, that this Government, in the circumstances where Mr Combe's name was raised by the Opposition and not by us, immediately did every possible thing it could do to ensure that Mr Combe had an unparalleled and historically unprecendented opportunity of knowing why the Government had acted as it did.
I repeat that once Mr Combe had had that opportunity with his lawyer, the Attorney-General and the Director-General of ASIO he indicated that he understood and accepted . . .
Now, Mr Speaker, nothing could be clearer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep going.
—Sure, I will keep going. I continue:

ANSWER.PARA: The decision of the Government that the Ministers of this Government would not have any further dealings with him in his capacity as a professional lobbyist. That decision taken by the Government was understood and accepted by Mr Combe. I repeat that, in the interests of Mr Combe, once his name had been deliberately introduced into this House and therefore to the public by the Opposition, this Government moved to do everything immediately within its power to see that Mr Combe had every opportunity to look at the facts--

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts!
—That is right. I continue:

ANSWER.PARA: as we, the Government, knew those facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't see the facts.

—As the honourable member wants to go on with it-he has a masochistic streak-let me repeat exactly what happened; honourable members either believe it or they do not. On the morning in question Mr Combe had lengthy discussions with the Attorney-General and for part of that time, as I said, the Director-General of ASIO was present. Then Mr Combe, with his lawyer-Mr Combe having talked to his lawyer-had full discussions with the Attorney-General. At any point in those discussions, as was made clear by the Attorney-General, if Mr Combe wanted any further clarification it was open to him. No impediment was put in the way of what Mr Combe could see, if he was not satisfied with all that had been read out . Mr Combe had every opportunity with his lawyer in those discussions with the Attorney-General which followed Mr Combe's discussion with the Attorney-General and the Director-General of ASIO. At the end of those proceedings Mr Combe agreed with the statement as given. Honourable members will see that everything I said in the House was strictly in accordance with the facts.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude by saying that later this day I will seek leave to make a statement to this House announcing the appointment of a royal commission under Mr Justice Hope. I make it clear that I will be saying in that statement that one of the terms of reference will put before the royal commissioner all the actions of this Government in regard to this matter. I look forward to all the actions of this Government in regard to this matter being studied and examined by the royal commissioner. I trust that in the reference that will be given to the royal commissioner not only will the actions of this Government be examined, but also all the actions of all members in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Given the importance of home interest rates to the electors of Australia and, of course, to those in my electorate of Stirling, can he advise the House of the likely impact, if any, on home interest rates of the latest sale of $400m of Treasury notes at yields below 10 per cent?

—It is true, as the honourable member for Stirling says, that the latest Treasury note tender did reveal a substantial drop in rates-a drop, on average, from about 11 per cent to 9 1/2 per cent. This is a most welcome decline, as indeed has been the general decline in other categories of interest rates-bond yields, bank deposit rates, secondary market rates and prime interest rates. I pick up the point raised by the honourable member for Lilley in the notice of motion she gave earlier. This does indicate a degree of confidence in financial markets in the Government's policies, not only in domestic markets but also in international markets, particularly in respect of capital inflow. It is true that rates have declined in a period of relatively easy liquidity occasioned by the effects of the Commonwealth Budget deficit in the second half of the year and also substantial capital inflow in April. I indicate again that I think the confidence factor is permeating abroad and I hope it will continue. If there is a general continuing decline in interest rates, there is, of course, the possibility that rates in the controlled area could also come down. This is an issue which the Government is keeping under review. I am keeping in touch with the banking community on that issue. Given the fact that in January rates in the controlled area declined by about one per cent, the banks have indicated that the first time they believe it is commercially possible to do so rates will decline. That matter will be kept under review.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has the Special Minister of State advised the Prime Minister of the extreme pressure to which he is subject because of the very sensitive and very confidential matters coming across his desk almost every hour of the day, his being expected to be at meetings morning, noon and night, doing a lot of travelling and trying to keep up with the material that is put before him? In view of this pressure, I ask the Prime Minister whether he is satisfied that the only breach of security during the course of the 3 1/2 hour luncheon in a restaurant attended by the Special Minister of State, Mr Rod Cameron of Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd and several leading Canberra lobbyists was the advice that the Government was about to kick out a Russian?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for Gwydir for his laudatory question in respect of the Special Minister of State. He indeed accurately reflects the great deal of work which is so effectively undertaken by my colleague. The Special Minister of State is a model of industriousness and, as we all know, of joviality. It is a matter of public record now that this joviality and spontaneity of my colleague did lead him to make an observation-he was referring to the fact that he had not been contactable for some two days by Mr Cameron-at about 12.30 on the day in question that we were about to kick out a Russian. I have indicated to the Minister, with an appropriate degree of reprimand, that that was not an appropriate thing for him to say. I accept without any question whatsoever the accuracy of what the Minister told me-that from the moment he made that comment at about 12.30 p.m. to the point at which the Minister for Foreign Affairs announced, about two hours later, the expulsion of Mr Ivanov, Mr Cameron had been with him at all times.
—He went off to answer a telephone call.

—There was no opportunity for Mr Cameron to take any action. I know that the honourable member for Barker would not imply this. I trust that he is not implying that in fact Mr Cameron would take such action.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the rest of the honourable member's question. He asked whether I was satisfied that in the rest of the period nothing was said in that conversation which in any way went to questions of security. Obviously the honourable member' s question is prompted by some observations and an article by Mr Toohey in the National Times, which carried the suggestion that my colleague the Minister had conveyed to Mr Cameron some relationship between Mr Ivanov and Mr Combe. That was said in an article which contained very many inaccuracies, and this was another of them. That is attested to now by two subsequent facts which I know the honourable member, being indeed an honourable gentleman, will accept. The first is that Mr Cameron himself has issued a statement totally supporting the statement which has been issued by the Minister. Secondly, as indeed the honourable member will understand, Mr Combe himself has now said that Mr Cameron in that period did not convey this relationship or suggestion between Ivanov and Combe to my colleague the Minister and that it must have been an inference drawn by Mr Combe. I am sure that when the honourable member takes into account all the facts which I have just put to him he will understand, as I do, that while it was not appropriate for the Minister to have made the statement that he did, he has in all other respects acted as we, that is the honourable member and me, would expect him to do-with honour and propriety.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask him: What position will the Australian Government advocate to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the national wage case, which is scheduled to begin on 28 June?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Phillip will be aware that a conference was held on 28 April in regard to future proceedings. As I understand it a further conference is scheduled for 23 May. I know that the honourable member, as indeed would all members of the House, understands that it would not be appropriate for me in the House to detail all the submissions that we will be putting to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission when a national wage case starts. Nevertheless, I am in a position to say something about this matter in terms of conveying to the honourable member and to the House the essential position of the Government.

QUESTION.PARA: Firstly, the submission of the Government will essentially be based upon the consensus position that was fundamentally arrived at at the National Economic Summit Conference, and that is that there should be a return to a centralised system of wage fixation. I say parenthetically that, given the indications made in this chamber during the National Economic Summit Conference of employers and State governments, I would be very surprised if the position of this Government, of the essentiality of a return to a centralised wage fixation system, was not supported by the employers and by most, if not all, of the State governments. Secondly, I can say to the honourable member that we will be saying to the Commission that any increase that may be granted in the latter part of 1983 should be small because we believe, as we have said in this House, outside it and at the Summit, that current economic circumstances and the reality of the economic environment and the industrial relations environment demand that any wage increase be small. Thirdly, I can say that we will be stressing, as indeed the Summit did, that any wage rises outside the national wage case should be strictly contained. Now you, Mr Speaker, can see, and I trust the honourable member also can see, that in those three elements I have set out the essential nature of the Government's submission.

In conclusion may I say that that policy, which is coherent, equitable and workable, is in distinct contrast to the position of the Opposition. I refer very briefly to an article on the front page of the Australian Financial Review of 5 May which, in relation to the Opposition's wages policy, stated:
At a joint meeting of the Liberal and National parties in Canberra yesterday the issue--
A centralised or decentralised approach to wage fixation-

was sent to an all-party committee after no senior frontbencher could lay claim to there being an Opposition wages policy. The scene is now set for months of manoeuvring between the decentralists, led by Shadow Treasurer Mr Howard, and the centralists, headed by Employment and Industrial Relations spokesman, Mr Ian Macphee.

In these circumstances, where we have on this side of the House a clear, coherent, equitable wages policy, I ask that the Leader of the Opposition at least direct himself to and answer in this House whether the position of the Opposition is one of support-yes or no-for a system of centralised wage fixation and to clear up once and for all whether the Opposition has anything remotely resembling a wages policy.

—Is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of the widespread concern in the community about the ruthless exploitation of Australian native birds and animals by unscrupulous exporters, operating in many cases outside the law? Can the Minister inform the House of any action that the Government is taking to control this trade, particularly in endangered species of Australian wildlife?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware of the great interest of most Australians in their rich and unique heritage of plants and animals. I believe that Australians fully accept their responsibility to care for Australian wildlife and are concerned to ensure that its survival is not jeopardised by ruthless and illegal exploitation.
—Does that include national secretaries of the Labor Party?
—Order!
—Oh, that was funny! We've got a comedian now.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister continue.

—This matter is concerned with birds. This Government recognises the concern and is particularly sensitive to the conservation needs of Australian wildlife. Strict controls will be maintained on the export of native wildlife and every effort will be made to stop illegal trade. Prior to the proclamation of the Wildlife Protection Act a public information program is to be mounted seeking the co-operation of all Australians. Under the provisions of the Act very severe penalties will be imposed on persons or organisations convicted of offences. Such penalties are appropriate to the high rewards available for illegal trafficking in wildlife. Every effort will be made to enforce this new legislation and to stop illegal trade, which not only poses a threat to the survival of species but also results in cruelty and death after prolonged suffering to many smuggled animals. By seeking and encouraging the co-operation of all Australians to help stop this repulsive activity, I am hopeful that it will be stamped out. I assure the honourable member that the Government, in consultation with the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers from the States, will continue to work against the operations of smugglers of our native birds and animals.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. I ask the Minister whether he recalls, when taking his oath as a Minister, swearing that he would not 'directly or indirectly reveal such matters as shall be debated in Council and committed to his secrecy'. I ask the Minister whether he regards his statement to Mr Cameron in relation to the expulsion of Ivanov as consistent with that oath?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —I was so excited-I had just been shown the salaries of Ministers-that I forgot what really the commitment was when I was sworn in. I can understand why Malcolm cried when he lost the election.

ANSWER.PARA: For three or four days we have listened to honourable members of the Opposition carry on around the country about what a threat it was to the national security that I happened to tell a person coming to lunch with me that in that afternoon we were going to kick out a Russian, and that that happened to be the explanation for my having been so rude to him for the past two days. It was honest, but it was a mistake. The Prime Minister has pointed that out and I have obviously been embarrassed by it. I wish it had not occurred. But to lay charges that in some way this was the gravest threat to national security since Federation, as did 'Scruffy' over here, the honourable member for New England-he is known to his close friends in Sydney as Scruffy-I think it is a great nickname for him--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—I ask that the Minister withdraw.
—Let me just point out--
—Order! The honourable member for New England finds the remark offensive.

—I withdraw. It is not a name I thought up. Quite seriously, the Opposition devalues the currency of an important subject when it lays charges about the importance of my indiscretion, because when it cries wolf in future no one at all will listen. There is a difference of opinion between the parties in this country about the national security, what is in its interest and how it is affected. For instance, during the 1960s we happened to think it was in the national interest to stop the Vietnam war. Those who are now in Opposition thought it was in the national interest to keep burning down the villages. The Opposition thought it was in the interests of the national security of Australia to recognise Pol Pot, so that he could wipe out three or four million Kampucheans. We did not think that was in the national interest, but they are the sorts of decisions which the present Opposition then made.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—We did not think that was in the national interest. We did not think it was in the national interest for a major portion of the work of members of the security forces of this country to stand on top of buildings and take photographs of those of us who were marching against the Vietnam War. We did not think that was the proper operation of the security forces of this country. We did not think it was in the best interests of this country to take the names of decent Australians who happened to want to demonstrate against what they thought was an infamous decision by the former Liberal governments of Menzies, Holt, Gorton and McMahon, to involve ourselves in Indo-China. So there is a very big difference in the emphasis that we put on national security.

ANSWER.PARA: I made a mistake and I have admitted to it. But for the Opposition to carry on about what is in the interests of national security and about how the national security of this country is affected is nonsense. I just wish it had the guts to do today what everyone said it would do, and move the censure motion. We would have given it plenty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, much as I do not like cutting off this debate--
—I suggest that the honourable member proceed straight to his question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I ask: Is the Government presently undertaking a review of the forward estimates of expenditure? Has such a review been attempted in earlier years? Do the results of those previous attempts at pruning forward estimates square with the claims made since the Federal elections by the various leftovers from the former Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Casey for his question. Honourable members of the House will recall the massive deception which was perpetrated on not only the Australian Labor Party but also all the people of Australia at the time of the last election. They will recall that during the election campaign the then Treasurer, the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, said that he thought the deficit for 1983-84 would be about $6 billion. When, the day after the election, the Prime Minister was presented with Government estimates for 1983-84 suggesting that the deficit would not be $6 billion but $9.6 billion, the former Treasurer was asked how he came up with his $6 billion estimate. He said that he thought that that was a reasonable sort of figure that could be achieved under the circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: It took only a few days before he got a bit of gratuitous assistance from his former and esteemed leader who presented to an awe-struck world a Liberal Party document which purported to give the details of the success of former Liberal Treasurers in dealing with problems of deficits. It is with some great degree of hesitation that I refer to a Liberal Party document because we know about the authenticity of documents which come out of 'Menzies House' down the road. We recall, of course, the Liberal Party's trick to distort the prices and incomes accord by leaving crucial pages out as it leaked it to the Press. We also recall , of course, that it was Liberal Party operatives who broke into the advertising agency of the Labor Party and then cooked up a document which purported to be an official Labor Party document.

So, we know about the authenticity of documents which come from the Liberal Party. But, let us accept just for a moment that the document that the former Prime Minister was referring to was, in fact, accurate. He said that that document indicated that in 1976 the then Government had been able to reduce a prospective deficit of $4.8 billion to $2.6 billion. Again, in 1978, he said that the Government had been able to reduce a prospective $6 billion deficit to $3 billion. It ought to be recognised that there are two ways in which one can deal with a prospective deficit. The first, of course, is to reduce the level of outlays; the other is to increase the level of revenue. Therefore, I thought it would be interesting to find out exactly what was the record of the former Government in relation to these two determinants of the prospective deficits. What we found out--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a message to us that you will put up taxes?

—Hang on a bit, my friend. Of course, the honourable member for O' Connor knows all about local government deficits and how to cook them. He knows all about the Carnarvon shire and how to put up taxes for selective ratepayers.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister and the honourable member for O' Connor remember that they are in the House.

—In 1976, although the then Government may have been able to reduce the prospective deficit by $2.2 billion, it was able to reduce outlays by only $ 1.5 billion. In 1978 it may have been able to reduce the overall deficit by $3 billion, but it reduced the outlays by only $1.1 billion. That means, of course, that it increased the level of taxation in 1976 by $1.1 billion and in 1978 by $ 1.9 billion. It is little wonder that Senator Withers said of his former leader that he was much more of a taxer than an axer. We know that Senator Withers knows more than anyone about the use of sharp instruments.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the record of the former Government. In 1979-80 it was able to trim just $680m off the prospective deficit outlays, the next year a mere $105m, the next year $650m and then, of course, in the last year-the great year, 1982- 83-it was actually able to achieve an increase in outlays of nearly a billion dollars as it attempted the most disgraceful exercise of trying to buy itself back into office at the end of last year. Of course that failed just as the former Government was doomed to failure.

Finally, what the former Treasurer had in mind for the unsuspecting Australian people when he said that he could reduce the prospective deficit which he admitted he knew about-the prospective $9.6 billion deficit which he said he could get down to $6 billion; that is, he could reduce it by $3.6 billion-was not a reduction in the outlays but in fact a massive $4.6 billion increase in taxes. That would have resulted in a $15 per week increase in taxes for every Australian taxpayer. That is the record against which this Government has proceeded with its expenditure review procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister wind up his answer. It is rather long.
—That is the mess that was presented to this Government and that is the record which should be judged against the statement which will be made by the Treasurer on Thursday of this week.

—I ask the Prime Minister: Is Mr W. P. Butler a member of the Government's ministerial staff advisory panel? Does he participate in decisions to select staff for employment in ministerial offices? Are applicants aware of the role Mr Butler plays and, in particular, does he sign letters to successful applicants? Is this the same Bill Butler who was an associate in a lobbying business, amongst other things, with Mr Richard Farmer and at one time a potential partner of Mr David Combe? Does the Prime Minister see any potential for conflict of interest in a situation where a lobbyist is involved in placing staff in ministerial offices?

—I will answer the last part of the question first. To my knowledge Mr Butler has not been and is not a lobbyist. I say that subject to correction but as far as I know Mr Butler has not been and is not a lobbyist.
—Nor is Richard Farmer.

—I am indebted for the assistance. As to this point in my Ministry there has not been-and so there shall not be now or in the future-any dissension between any of us. I make it clear that the intervention by the Minister for Housing and Construction accords with my understanding of the position. Therefore, as to the basis of the question from the Leader of the Opposition, I repeat that Mr Butler, to whom he refers, has not been and is not a lobbyist. The substance of the question disappears. I will now go on to say what is the position of the Government in respect of the selection of staff and what is the position of Mr Butler. It is the case, as is well known-a fact of which we are proud as a government-that the Government has appointed a ministerial staff advisory panel to assess the merits of all prospective employees before they are considered for appointment to ministerial staffs. In the context of that approach to this matter, the Government placed a general advertisement for ministerial staff positions to attract the best possible people to serve in those positions. I am pleased to say, and I suggest it is not a matter of surprise, that we had about 2,000 applicants for those positions. In those circumstances the applicants are considered by the ministerial staff advisory panel and recommendations are made for those positions. I have a final right to approve or not to approve those recommendations. I should also add that the same Mr Butler is chairman of that ministerial staff advisory panel.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED NUCLEAR FREE ZONE IN THE PACIFIC

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether he can confirm the remark attributed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs that Australia supports the proposed nuclear free zone in the Pacific but will nonetheless support United States warship and aircraft activity in the South Pacific. Are these two proposals consistent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The countries of the South Pacific, including Australia, are strongly opposed to the testing and storing of nuclear weapons in the region and to the dumping of nuclear waste in the South Pacific. My Government is strictly of that view. At the same time as we have that view, Australia is concerned that we do not endanger our alliance relationship with the United States of America. In particular we do not wish to impede the passage of United States nuclear powered and armed vessels through the Pacific or port calls by United States vessels in the region nor, of course, do we wish to impede the right of United States aircraft in transitting international air space. The concept of a nuclear free zone has been discussed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden. He has discussed it in a number of areas. I understand he had some discussions about this with the United States Secretary of State, George Shultz, in Paris last Sunday.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to make it quite clear, so that there can be no doubt about it, that we shall continue to have discussions on these issues with our Pacific partners. I believe that the concepts involved would be an important item of discussion at the South Pacific Forum which is to be held in this city later on this year. I stress the two points and I repeat them: We have a concern which we share with, I believe, all countries in this region about the testing and storing of nuclear weapons and the dumping of nuclear waste. We have that concern at the same time as we have the concern to maintain our relationship with the United States, which I have referred to in more detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Trade consult with any of his colleagues or take advice from his Department before making his weekend comments criticising Japan's role in the Australian coal trade? Does the Minister's criticism of Japanese equity participation in Australian coal mines mean that the Government will discriminate against foreign equity participation in the Australian coal industry? If so, will the Minister tell the House how this would benefit our coal exports and employment in the coal industry in this difficult period? Finally, will the Minister tell the House why, if, as he claims, Australia has been 'taken to the cleaners' by Japan on coal prices, he gave his approval to those prices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the question. The reason I gave approval to the prices was that they were within the parameters set by the previous Government. I hope it admits that. I walked into office to find parameters that I could not improve because the previous Government had set them so low. Those parameters were $12 below the previous year's price. Therefore, how did the previous Government expect-
—You're the Government.
—I came into government after the honourable member; I have to inherit the former Government's problems.
—You didn't have to give approval.
—Yes, I did. Let me make it very clear. I ask the Leader of the National Party not to try to argue his way out of it. Mr Speaker, may I have a bit of silence?
—Order! The Leader of the National Party was able to ask his question in silence. I suggest that he respect the answer.

—The honourable member does not like the attack because he gave the parameters which guaranteed that we would sell coal at a loss. I can inform him that we sold the same amount of coal pursuant to his parameters which guarantees the Australian people receive $300m less than they did last year for the same amount of coal. Where was the honourable member's interest in Australia when he set the parameters so low? I make it very clear that because of the previous Government's idea of selling coal, the agreement that we had to inherit was that parameters would be set by the honourable member who asked the question and that the various people who own the coal-there are plenty of them-all went over to Tokyo and tried to negotiate the best deal possible. One can imagine what the Japanese did to them. They called them up one by one from their hotel rooms as and when the Japanese wanted to see them. That was the position. One can imagine Australians going there with individual ideas, because that was their brilliant concept, and meeting the Japanese who had only one idea and one price-that is, the lowest possible one that they could get for Japan, and they did it. I repeat: Good luck to the Japanese if they can put the cleaners through the likes of the honourable member. That is the problem. But it cost us $300m. We now have coal mines in Australia that have sold coal at a loss-at less than what it cost to produce.
—What did you bring them home for?
—Well, they had to come eventually. They went broke over there. What is the reason for that?
—They went--
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—Why does the honourable member not ask a supplementary question ? That would be a better arrangement. The previous Government had an attractive interest in what it called foreign investment. We do not mind foreign investment as long as it is not against Australian interests. Have a look at the foreign investment policies the former Government adopted. The former Goverment guaranteed that foreign investors who came in here could open up as many mines as they liked, and this is what happened. We have a surplus of coal. However, of course, the Japanese have revised their estimates for coal down 100 per cent on the previous estimates which the previous Government was gullible enough to expect we would have a market for.
—Back to zero?
—In percentage terms. Why does the honourable member not go back to the Bar; he would make a better living if he did.
—Order!
—The point I am trying to make--
—I ask the Deputy Prime Minister to address the Chair.

—I was asked a wide-ranging question. I want to make the point: The question of foreign ownership and control is very significant. We welcome foreign investment provided there is a guarantee that Australia's resources are not sold at a loss.

ANSWER.PARA: The figures given to me by my Department-I knew that the honourable member might be thinking of asking me a question-clearly show that 51 per cent of the ownership of the 32 groups which participated in selling coal is foreign owned. I would also like to give the honourable member some further advice so that he does not ever make the same mistakes again, and I assure him that he will not get the chance to do so. Some of our unfortunate producers, apart from having Japanese equity in their own mines-and I might suggest the Japanese would know about this-have to negotiate sales with so-called Japanese trading companies when they go to Japan. I will not identify the companies but they are well known . Those companies charge a percentage on sales. So the final analysis-official- of my Department is this:

It must be recognised that conflict of interest is inherent in the role fulfilled by the trading companies and there can be little doubt that in such situations the interest of the Japanese consuming companies has prevailed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Special Minister of State seen today's Press reports of a number of papers to be presented at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Congress by senior counsel to the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, Mr Doug Meagher, Q.C.? What is the Government doing to combat organised crime in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I have seen reports of the papers to be delivered by the senior counsel assisting the Costigan Royal Commission. I would like to inform the House that following consultations between Commissioner Costigan, the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and me, the Government has agreed in principle to increase significantly the financial and staffing resources available to the Commissioner. The Commissioner is currently supported by a secretariat of approximately 70 people and financial expenditure to date has been approximately $6m. Additional professional legal staff, intelligence collators, research, records and automatic data processing staff will be recruited and the Commission itself will move into bigger premises . Sophisticated computer-based techniques are already in use by the Commission and these will be extended as part of the Government's thrust to ensure that Mr Costigan has all the resources he needs. It is expected that the cost for 1983- 84 will be in the order of $3.5m.

ANSWER.PARA: Initially, of course, it was thought that the Commission's investigation would be confined to the illegal activities of painters and dockers in such relatively minor areas as ghosting, illegal payments and other fraud on their employers. However, interim reports from the Commission have highlighted Painters and Dockers' direct involvement in organised crime generally, and particularly in white collar crime like corporate fraud and the tax avoidance industry. In relation to the proposed national crimes commission, the Government is particularly concerned at the extent of organised crime in Australia, as identified in a number of recent royal commission reports, including those by Commissioners Williams, Costigan and Stewart. In this regard, the Government recognises that ad hoc royal commissions may not be the most effective way to combat organised crime. In a joint Press statement with the Attorney-General on 7 April, I stated that I believed that there was almost universal support for the concept--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister should use the appropriate form of the House to read statements, rather than Question Time.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I support the concept of a permanent national crimes commission. However, there remains a good deal of uncertainty and disagreement as to the most appropriate functions, composition and powers of such a body. The Government has decided that a further process of consultation and review is necessary before any final decision is taken on the future of the national crimes commission.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to these matters, under its broad operational charter the Australian Federal Police accords highest priority to combating organised crime, particularly drug trafficking. In view of the widespread nature of organised crime which has been exposed in recent times, the Australian Federal Police effort in this area has increased rapidly. The AFP participates in a number of measures, both individually and in co-operation with other police and investigators. Over one-third of all the AFP's detective force is now deployed in support of royal commissions, special police task forces, and special prosecutors investigating special instances of organised crime.

I assure the House that under this Government there will be no let-up in the attack on organised crime in this country. The immoral behaviour of people who are participating in this field of criminal activity is costing decent, ordinary tax-paying Australians hundreds of millions of dollars that ought to have been used for much better purposes in this country. We will not let up in our efforts to make sure that all these inquiries, both that being conducted by Costigan and those being conducted by other commissioners, are concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In the course of an answer earlier today the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) misled the House in two respects. Firstly, he falsely asserted that when, during the election campaign, I made reference to a figure of $6,000m in relation to the 1983-84 Budget deficit. I was aware, or had been informed, of the starting point figure of $9.6 billion subsequently referred to in his speech . That statement is wrong, misleading and a total mistruth. I reject it completely.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Minister for Finance also misled the House in asserting that when I made the highly qualified reference during the election campaign to a figure of $6,000m I had in contemplation tax increases of $4.6 billion. The truth, of course, is that I made reference to a figure of $6 billion some five days after the delivery of the Australian Labor Party's election campaign promises which, incidentally, totally repudiates the proposition of the Treasurer that those promises were made in the mistaken belief that next year's deficit would be $6 billion. I point out to the House and to the Minister for Finance that all those promises were made by the Labor Party without the former Government having any reference at all to the figure of $6 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is now going beyond a personal explanation.
—They know that.
—The honourable member has gone beyond a personal explanation. He will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented and I wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I draw attention to a newspaper article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, 14 May. In this article the journalist, Mr Peter Bowers, discussed the events of 12 May, that is, the events surrounding the announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of a royal commission into the so-called Ivanov-Combe affair and claimed, first, that the Prime Minister phoned me. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Hawke arranged for Theophanous to toss him a frienddly question during question time to start at noon.
Secondly, the article stated:
Bowen's office, alerted by a phone call from Theophanous, tells Bowen that Hawke will announce a Royal Commission in Parliament during question time, to start at noon.

Mr Speaker, both of these claims are false. Let me deal with them in order. With regard to the first matter of the contact between myself and the Prime Minister it is interesting to contrast this account with the one which appeared in the Melbourne Herald on the same day and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should not contrast accounts. He should explain how he has been misrepresented; otherwise his comments could lead to a general debate. I invite him to follow the Standing Orders.

—After substantial thought about the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and Combe affair on Wednesday night I approached the Whip early on Thursday morning and asked for a priority question to the Prime Minister on the problem of the accountability of ASIO and subsequent courses of action open to the Government. Soon after, the Prime Minister asked to see me and a discussion between us ensued regarding the matter. Although I urged the Prime Minister to make an immediate statement giving an indication of the Government's course of action I did not insist on the announcement of a judicial inquiry or a royal commission on that day.

SPEECH.PARA: The Melbourne Herald inferred that I was aware that the Prime Minister would announce a royal commission on that day. This is not the case. It follows from this that the Sydney Morning Herald's claim that I phoned the office of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) prior to Question Time in relation to this matter is completely false. The Deputy Prime Minister is prepared to confirm that I did not talk to him or to his office in relation to this matter. Let me say in conclusion that I completely concur with the Prime Minister's announcement of a royal commision on that day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is now going beyond the scope of a personal explanation.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-A royal commission has now been appointed to conduct a major review of Australian security and intelligence agencies, with a term of reference relating to all the circumstances-including the actions of the Government-surrounding the expulsion of Mr Ivanov and the involvement of Mr David Combe in those circumstances. The terms of reference have already been circulated to honourable members. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —This demonstrates the Chair's flexibility in relation to incorporations in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: The document read as follows-
ELIZABETH THE SECOND, by the Grace of God Queen of Australia and Her other Realms and Territories, Head of the Commonwealth:
TO THE HONOURABLE MR JUSTICE ROBERT MARSDEN HOPE, C.M.G., Judge of Appeal, Supreme Court of New South Wales
GREETING:

WHEREAS it is desired to have a judicial review of the activities of Australia' s security and intelligence agencies, namely, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, the Defence Signals Directorate, the Joint Intelligence Organisation and the Office of National Assessments (hereinafter called ''the agencies''):

NOW THEREFORE We do by these Our Letters Patent issued in Our name by Our Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia on the advice of the Federal Executive Council and in pursuance of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia, the Royal Commissions Act 1902 and other enabling powers, appoint you to be a Commissioner to inquire into, and in relation to-

(a) the activities of the agencies, especially since the completion of the inquiry made by the Royal Commission appointed on 21 August 1974 to inquire into matters relating to the intelligence and security services of the Australian Government (hereinafter called the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security ), with particular reference to-
(i) the progress made in implementing Government decisions on the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security and of the Protective Security Review;

(ii) whether the agencies have efficiently, effectively and properly served the interests of the Australian people and Government, including whether effective arrangements exist for the establishment of policies and priorities, for the co- ordination of their activities and for the oversight of their work;
(iii) whether any changes in existing law and practices are required ordesirable-
(A) to ensure that the agencies are properly accountable to Ministers and the Parliament;
(B) in relation to keeping the Leader of the Opposition informed on matters relating to security and intelligence;
(C) to provide for proper safeguarding, including safeguarding against unauthorised publication, of intelligence, including information provided by foreign governments in confidence;
(iv) whether there is adequate provision for effective redress for any persons who may be unjustifiably disadvantaged by actions of the agencies;
(v) whether existing law enables effective oversight by the Auditor-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization and the Australian Secret Intelligence Service in financial matters;

(b) whether the activities of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization , especially since the completion of the inquiry made by the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security, have been carried out in compliance with the law, in particular the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1956, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979, the Telephonic Communications (Interception) Act 1960 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979;

(c) further to the inquiry in relation to paragraphs (a) and (b) above, all the circumstances, including the actions of the Government, surrounding the expulsion from Australia of Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov, First Secretary, Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and the involvement of Mr Harvey David Mathew Combe in those circumstances; and
(d) any other related matters to which the attention of the Commission is directed by the Prime Minister in the course of the inquiry:
AND We require you as expeditiously as possible to make your inquiry and to furnish to Our Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia-
(e) first and as soon as possible, a report of the results of your inquiry and recommendations in relation to the matters specified in paragraph (c); and

(f) a report or reports as soon as possible, and in any event not later than 30 June 1984, of the results of your inquiry and recommendations in relation to the matters specified, or referred to, in paragraphs (a), (b) and (d).

WITNESS His Excellency the Right Honourable Sir Ninian Martin Stephen, a Member of Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council, Knight of the Order of Australia , Knight Grand Cross of The Most Distinguished Order of Saint Michael and Saint George, Knight Grand Cross of The Royal Victorian Order, Knight Commander of The Most Excellent Order of the British Empire, Knight of the Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem, Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia and Commander-in-Chief of the Defence Force.
Dated this day of 1983.
Governor-General
By His Excellency's Command,
Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —The royal commissioner is Mr Justice Hope, Judge of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales. Counsel assisting the royal commissioner will be Mr D. M. Ryan, QC, of the Melbourne Bar. I wish to express my gratification at the availability of Mr Justice Hope, and His Honour's acceptance of the commission. As honourable members will be well aware, Mr Justice Hope has already inquired into and reported on the intelligence and security services of the Australian Government in a series of major reports in 1976 and 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: The appointment of the royal commission initiates the implementation of my Government's policy for regular judicial audit of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and close scrutiny of the role and activities of the intelligence community generally. On the occasion of the opening of Parliament the Governor-General conveyed my Government's commitment to amending the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act of 1979 to define more precisely the Organisation's jurisdiction and to ensure its private and public accountability. As I have already indicated to the Parliament, this is not something that is being imposed on the agencies concerned. I have had discussions with their heads, making it clear to them that it was appropriate that there should be a judicial review. That point has been accepted by them, and indeed it has been welcomed by them.

As foreshadowed in Parliament last week, the first matter on which the royal commissioner is being asked to report concerns the circumstances surrounding the expulsion of Mr Ivanov, and the involvement of Mr David Combe in those circumstances. The terms of reference have been drafted to enable the inquiry to extend to the actions of all relevant persons and organisations, including the Government, in respect of these matters. The royal commissioner has been asked to make his report on these matters as soon as possible.

The whole reason for this royal commission is the Government's own mismanagement of the Ivanov matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I said last week that it was the answer of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in this House which created this problem. I said that he should have stuck to convention-that is, no public disclosure; a refusal to confirm or deny. That is what he should have done. That remains true today. However, we now know that his statements in the Caucus and in the Parliament only exacerbated the problem. We now know that the Leader of the House (Mr Young) commenced the innuendoes, and he has been rebuked. Rebuked-is that all that happens to a Minister who leaks matters of national security? This Prime Minister, by not widening the terms of reference to investigating the conflicting statements of Mr Combe and Mr Young, has shown that he will tolerate leaks of national security within his own Government. There can be only one greater or more serious dereliction of duty than a Minister leaking national security matters and that is a Prime Minister acknowledging and tacitly concurring in it. A rebuke? What is that? We have already had five Ministers rebuked. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) was rebuked for criticising and dumping it on koalas. The same punishment is meted out in this matter. Koala kicking is equated with national security leaks. Some conduct!

The Combe affair has undoubtedly brought disgrace on the Government. It has shown a callous disregard for the civil liberties of an Australian citizen. It has displayed extraordinary ineptitude. It has acted with quite astonishing indiscretion. The severity of this whole sorry affair has made this royal commission necessary. I should say that I am pleased to note that the Prime Minister was able to persuade the Cabinet to endorse his decision. He must have done it against considerable opposition. We hardly need to be reminded that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) described such a judicial inquiry as bizarre, and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) does not think it helpful to Mr Combe. So it comes as no suprise that the Cabinet, I suppose in the light of recent statements, has rejected the opinions of the Deputy Prime Minister.

Although the royal commission will be empowered to examine the extraordinary circumstances of the Combe affairs, it is imperative that the royal commission examine two particular issues. First, it must establish the identity of the person or persons who leaked details of Mr Combe's involvement to Canberra lobbyists and the Press. It is that leak which, above all, has led to the public humiliation of Mr Combe. Secondly, the royal commission must examine very serious allegations that no less a person than the Prime Minister himself has misled this Parliament in an attempt to demonstrate that the Government has handled this matter fairly. These issues unquestionably strike at the heart of the Government's interpretation of fair, of just and, indeed, of democratic behaviour.

It was made clear to everyone by reports which appeared in the Sydney Telegraph of 8 May and the Sydney Morning Herald of 10 May that a senior member of the Labor Party was considered a potential security risk by the Government and was linked with Mr Ivanov. Contrary to established convention, as I have said, the Prime Minister, on 10 May, confirmed the name of Mr Combe in the Parliament. What is extraordinary about this episode is the way Mr Combe's name leaked out of the Government. The Opposition believes that the royal commission should examine the inference in the National Times of 13 May that the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) had been the source of the leak. In his statement of 13 May, the Minister openly admitted that he had acted unwisely and that the Prime Minister had expressed his 'concern'. The Minister accepted in that statement that he had, in effect, breached national security. The Prime Minister was only 'concerned'. A breach of national security by anyone, not least a Minister, is a most serious matter; and yet we have had simply the reprimand referred to today by the Prime Minister.

The honourable course of action by the Special Minister of State is for him to offer his resignation to the Prime Minister immediately. Mr Combe's subsequent comments in an interview with Mr Max Walsh, which were reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 16 May raise considerable doubts about the veracity of the Minister's statement of 13 May. In that interview, Mr Combe said:
When I left the National Press Club, I was in no doubt that a major probable reason for Ivanov's expulsion was that he was too close to people who could influence the Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: INQUIRY INTO SAFETY STANDARDS AT THE COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION APPLIED ORGANIC CHEMISTRY AND ADVANCED MATERIALS LABORATORIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I table the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Safety Standards at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Applied Organic Chemistry and Advanced Materials Laboratories at Fishermen's Bend, Melbourne, and the Death of CSIRO Employee Dr R. Bergamasco, or, to give it a more convenient name, the Andrew report, after its distinguished Chairman. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 April 1983 the Melbourne Sunday Press published the first of two articles about the death from malignant melanoma in December 1982 of a 33 -year-old CSIRO scientist, Dr Ron (Rinaldo) Bergamasco, who had worked in the Applied Organic Chemistry Laboratories at Fishermen's Bend, noting that three other scientists had died from cancer between 1977 and 1982, one from the Applied Organic Chemcistry Laboratory and two from the adjacent Division of Materials Science.

SPEECH.PARA: On 4 April, I asked CSIRO to prepare an immediate report. I made a personal inspection of both laboratories on Wednesday, 6 April and, following my recommendations, on 12 April the Government commissioned a committee of inquiry, with the following terms of reference:
(1) the safety of the working environment in the laboratories, the identification of factors which could put workers at risk and steps to be taken, if possible, to remedy such deficiencies, and
(2) factors, if any, which link the death of Dr Bergamasco with his working environment in the laboratories.

The Chairman of the Committee of Inquiry was Emeritus Professor R. R. Andrew A.O ., Director of Medical Education at St Frances Xavier Cabrini Hospital, Malvern, Victoria. Members of the Committee were Professor L. J. Opit, Department of Social and Preventive Medicine, Monash University, and Professor W. R. Jackson, Department of Chemistry (Organic), Monash University. Secretary to the Committee was Mr J. A. Froude of the Department of Science and Technology. The Committee met six times between 18 April and 9 May 1983, including a visit to the Fishermen's Bend site on 21 April. All members of the Committee were present at all meetings. Mr N. K. Hart, CSIRO Division of Applied Organic Chemistry, Fishermen's Bend, Dr G. Ash, Commonwealth Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, Canberra, and Dr J. B. Robinson, State Laboratories, Premier's Department, Victoria, were co-opted to the Committee for specialist functions.

I want to express the Government's thanks to the members of the Committee who worked under extreme pressure to produce a report at the earliest reasonable time for the Parliament. Given the very short time between the setting up of the Committee and the presentation of the report-barely four weeks-it is an exemplary piece of work. A considered response by the Government will be brought down, after full consultation with CSIRO, in the Budget session.

However, because of the widespread public concern and media reporting about safety standards in laboratories, and the death of Dr Bergamasco, the Committee' s findings should be summarised. The Andrew report concluded that in Building 53 , where Dr Bergamasco had worked:
1. the laboratories were severely crowded;
2. the exhaust from the house vacuum system is directly under and close to the air intake of the ventilation system;
3. the ventilation of the organic chemical store is inadequate;
4. the increase in number and efficiency of fume cupboards has led to a potential deficiency in the make-up air capacity of the building;
5. many fume cupboards did not achieve an adequate air flow velocity unless cupboard doors were opened only a minimal amount;

6. the exhausts from several auxiliary fume extractors had not been raised above roof level. Fumes could thus be recycled into the building through the many window-fitted air conditioning units or through the exhausts of fume cupboards that are not operating; and
7. that asbestos was still in use as bench sheets and in oven packing, being discarded and replaced by other material as it became necesssary to replace the equipment.
It should be noted that the Committee was far more critical of the Advanced Materials Laboratory which was described as being:
located in a collection of old buildings posing a severe fire hazard, and totally unsuitable for modern research.
The report concluded:
. . . the CSIRO Laboratories at Fishermens Bend must be regarded as providing a hazardous working environment.
The Committee recommended inter alia that:

2.6.1 The planned transfer of the Advanced Materials Laboratory to Clayton be accelerated as a matter of urgency and high priority. The CSIRO Executive had already concluded in 1980 that there was no feasible alternative to construction at Clayton, and that continued occupancy of the present site is holding up research of national importance.

2.6.2 Funding for and a detailed plan for the transfer of the Applied Organic Chemistry laboratories to Clayton be provided as a matter of urgency and high priority. It is suggested that the plan should incorporate the transfer of individual research groups as accommodation is made available at Clayton.

2.6.3 Funding for and a detailed design to upgrade and maintain the present air supply system be provided. This is considered necessary as it is anticipated that even given a favourable program, transfer to Clayton may not be completed until 1987.

2.6.12 The Committee considered that the provision of only one CSIRO safety officer in an Organization of some 40 Divisions at over 100 locations with an expenditure of some $267m per annum was not compatible with the CSIRO's image of a world renowned scientific organization. The Committee recommended the appointment of safety specialists in at least the major industrial States plus a service of such expertise to other States and the employment of full-time safety officers at sites of high hazard potential such as Fishermens Bend. One model which the Committee noted was that being set up in the Department of Defence Support.

2.6.13 The Committee further recommended that the Safety and Health Organization of CSIRO incorporating the staff and facilities outlined above should be structured in such a way that there is a continuing program of surveillance, education, training and research on health and safety matters. Further that the Safety and Health Organization should be structured as a unit separate from and not accountable administratively to any particular Division of CSIRO but rather provide a service to all.

2.6.16 The Committee believed that the Commonwealth Government has an opportunity to provide leadership to CSIRO-and other Commonwealth Organizations- in the field of Occupational Safety and Health including education and training.
On the question of Dr Bergamasco's death, the Committee concluded that it has:

. . . not found any evidence that Dr Bergamasco's tragic premature death was related to his occupation, nor to his work environment at the CSIRO Division of Applied Organic Chemistry at Fishermens Bend . . . In addition we have no knowledge of any actual body contamination by chemicals incurred by Dr Bergamasco. In the absence of any measures of exposure level or of any existing evidence known to the Committee linking melanoma with specific agents, whether causative or as promoters of tumour growth, it is not possible to link his death directly with his work.
The report noted that:

. . . the occurence of malignant melanoma in relation to the imparted dose of UV (i.e. ultra violet) light is well documented . . . It is important to note that in men, aged 30-34 years, malignant melanoma is recorded as the cause of death in 23 per cent of all deaths from cancer in this age group in Australia. It has the highest incidence rate of all cancers in this age group of males-18.3 per 100,000 per year in 1977-and the chance occurrence of one such case in 500 male workers over five years is not improbable.
I commend the Andrew report to the consideration of the House. I present the following paper:

Inquiry into Safety Standards at the Commonwealth Scientific Industrial Research Organisation Applied Organic Chemistry and Advanced Materials Laboratories-Report and Ministerial Statement, 17 May 1983.
Motion by (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr. H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the Government's actions in relation to the matters canvassed in the previous ministerial statement I am bound to say that in the context of the media publicity surrounding the death of Dr Bergamasco the prompt action of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) in setting up so distinguished, independent and highly qualified a committee of inquiry, is to be commended. Further, the Opposition joins with the Minister and the Government in expressing appreciation of the work of the Committee of Inquiry into Safety Standards at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Applied Organic Chemistry and Advanced Materials Laboratories. It has worked very hard indeed to produce a report to present to the Parliament in the current sittings in view of the widespread public concern about safety standards at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's laboratories in general and any possible relationship to Dr Bergamasco's death in particular. The Minister in his statement has set out the main findings and the major recommendations of the Committee. That the Applied Organic Chemistry and Advanced Materials Laboratories at Fishermens Bend have many inadequacies is undoubted. The Committee recommends that remedying the situation be regarded as a matter of urgency and high priority. I know that my predecessor, the honourable David Thomson, was of the same opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the Committee's second term of reference, the tragic early death of Dr Bergamasco, the Committee reports that it could find no evidence that this was related to his occupation and work environment. This form of cancer is unhappily, I understand, most prevalent in this younger age group. Our sympathy goes out to the late Dr Bergamasco's relatives and friends. As the Minister has stated that a considered response by the Government will be brought down in the Budget session I seek leave to continue my remarks at that time.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
