DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The uncertainty created by the Government's confusing, contradictory and provocative statements in relation to South East Asia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past 36 hours, as the result of remarks by the Deputy Prime Minister and Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Lionel Bowen) the nation's international reputation and the reputation of this Government have been exposed to a negative public reaction and that negative public reaction has been mixed with concern and ridicule. In proposing an Australian-Japanese peacekeeping force for service in Kampuchea, without thought , without consultation with the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), the Cabinet, the Japanese and other interested governments, the Deputy Prime Minister, who, let me remind honourable members, holds the second highest office in the Government of Australia, has brought Australia's foreign policy into serious international discredit.

SPEECH.PARA: This nation is faced this afternoon with a Press and electronic media virtually unanimous in its concern and condemnation at the disarray caused by this Government's amateurish efforts in making foreign policy. There is concern at the division within the Government, which this incident illustrates. The Foreign Minister was obliged to dissociate himself from the proposition. He denied knowledge of the Deputy Prime Minister's plan, saying: Anything like that would be a long way off. Thus this morning's headlines read: 'Bowen plan surprise to Hayden', in the Canberra Times; 'Hayden-Bowen Brawl', in the Australian Financial Review; 'Hayden and Bowen in Conflict', in the Daily Telegraph; and ' Hayden and Bowen clash over Troops', in the Australian.

There is concern at the failure of the Deputy Prime Minister as Acting Foreign Minister to test his thinking with the Department of Foreign Affairs. Undoubtedly, the Deputy Prime Minister consoles himself by reference to his motive-the motive of mobilising resources for a peaceful settlement. It is an estimable motive, but that is all the more reason why he needs to equip himself with professional advice-which is readily at hand, and I am quite sure would be given without fear or bias.

Australia is fortunate in having a diplomatic service of skill and experience. The actions of the Deputy Prime Minister in making this 'off-the-cuff' foray are inexcusable when one considers that there was no public pressure for him to deliver this 'kerb-side' opinion. It is for him to justify his action; not in terms of his intent or the lack of intent on the part of others, but in terms of his failure to use competently the very sizable resources of advice available to him. This issue raises the question of his basic competence to act as Foreign Minister. Australia's international reputation has suffered a considerable blow. The result of his actions has left the public of Australia and the Opposition gravely concerned that the Deputy Prime Minister showed no understanding of the long and difficult history that surrounds the role of the Japanese Self Defence Forces.

Many Australians are well aware of internal debate in Japan over the clause in the Japanese constitution which precludes the maintenance of Japanese armed forces for general defence use. The Japanese have only with difficulty reconciled with the constitution the establishment of a role for self-defence forces. I remind the House that in 1971 there was a proposal put forward for Japanese self-defence forces to be used overseas on humanitarian relief. This proposal was not received at all well and raised a great storm within Japan. If only a preliminary enquiry to the Department of Foreign Affairs had been made, the Deputy Prime Minister would have saved himself a lot of embarrassment and ridicule, and been put on the right track. Did this experienced politician follow this tried and tested procedure before he made his announcement? Not a bit of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait till you hear me.

—Consequently, we are left with a very unpretty picture-front page banner headlines in Japan, with consequences that we cannot at this stage describe or foresee. Public condemnation in Australia has been swift and direct. Let me quote some of the Australian editorial which is headed: 'This silly idea must be forgotten'.
—Who wrote that?
—This is the Australian editorial today. It says, among other things:

SPEECH.PARA: Not only is it impossible that the Deputy Prime Minister's proposal has the slightest chance of being accepted by the governments concerned, but the nature of his suggestion is such as to cause the rest of the world to have the gravest doubts about our government's understanding of the facts of international life.
That, Mr Deputy Speaker, is a very severe comment indeed, and I shall repeat it:
. . . but the nature of his suggestion is such as to cause the rest of the world to have the gravest doubts . . .

That, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have to say, is a general statement shared by many about the reputation the Government is getting for its foreign policy. This Government inherited a situation on foreign policy where Australia was held in high esteem internationally. Our relations with our friends in the Association of South East Asian Nations had never been brought into question on matters affecting basic security and regional relationships on security issues. ASEAN has rightly been regarded around the world as one of the most important and successful experiments in regional co-operation. Our policy gave priority to fostering its strengths. When it launched its successful international efforts to secure a majority United Nations position on Kampuchea, Australian diplomacy was very active in its support.

We now call on the Government to give continuing support to the United Nations resolution of last year, supported by 105 nations, proposing arrangements for a peaceful settlement and a withdrawal of the Vietnamese occupation forces. But the Government is still evasive. It says it supports the United Nations process. In opposition it criticised our peacekeeping in the Sinai in the absence of a United Nations resolution, but it refuses to endorse publicly the ASEAN-United Nations endorsed resolution on Vietnamese occupation of Kampuchea. The Opposition believes, and a great majority of Australians believe, that close and effective relations with our regional friends in ASEAN is fundamental to our international relations. Australians have many links at all levels of contact with individual members of ASEAN. We have as a nation been greatly heartened by the stability of ASEAN and the contribution that ASEAN is making to the wider region of the Pacific. ASEAN's economic growth is important to us. ASEAN security is scarcely divisible from ours, and that is why the majority of Australians accept the value of defence co-operation with ASEAN. But this Government has by its public diplomacy-if that is an appropriate word for the process; and I doubt very much that it is an appropriate word-downgraded our relations with ASEAN. It has sought to give the impression that ASEAN has positions which are difficult for us. All of this is unfortunate, if it was unintended, because it distorts the true value which the majority of Australians have come to place on our relations with ASEAN. We all know that the concern expressed by ASEAN about the apparent change of emphasis in our foreign policy priorities had disturbed our neighbours. They have had put to them that Australia is upgrading relations with Hanoi. The implication has been put on them that their efforts to bring Hanoi to the conference table have broken down. They have been asked to accept that Australia is capable of building with Hanoi a relationship that has eluded them and out of this relationship will issue processes which will lead to a settlement.

This Parliament needs to be reminded that ASEAN efforts with Hanoi, despite considerable provocation, have been outward-looking and constructive. Senior Vietnamese Ministers visited the ASEAN region. Malaysia's Foreign Minister and a Singapore trade delegation visited Vietnam in 1977. Then followed the refugee exodus of 1978-a problem not caused by ASEAN-and in 1980 Malaysia and Indonesia made a significant gesture towards Hanoi through a declaration called the Kuantan Declaration. This affirmed the need for Vietnam to be independent of both China and the Soviet Union. In 1981 ASEAN advanced proposals internationally which sought to accord some recognition of Vietnam's security interests in relation to Cambodia and which were intended to prevent the return of Pol Pot forces after a Vietnamese withdrawal.

So, Mr Deputy Speaker, the questions this House has to ask are as follows: Why this switch in priorities by this Government? Why this public diplomacy designed to throw ASEAN into a state of concern about Australia? Why at the same time seek to deliver aid to Hanoi? Why this promotion of the idea that Hanoi is ready to negotiate? Why risk so much misunderstanding from our friends for the distant prospects of Hanoi? Why avoid the path of quiet exploration of the issues first?

Many friends of Australia are led to wonder whether the high priority being given to relations with Hanoi is based on a technical estimate from the Department of Foreign Affairs that the time is now ripe to explore Hanoi's attitude to active negotiations, or whether the Government is deliberately creating a public situation to distance Australia from ASEAN-a situation which, of course, Hanoi would welcome. Far from encouraging settlement, such a result would lead Vietnam's hard-liners into the belief that international solidarity would be broken down. That is a serious risk to which the Government has exposed a very delicate situation for ASEAN. It is therefore very highly relevant to look again at the diplomacy of this Government on South-East Asia since it came into office.

The whole program of action is dictated by the Australian Labor Party resolutions of 1982, resolutions passed at a conference when the Deputy Prime Minister was the Labor Party's spokesman on foreign affairs and the Foreign Minister was then its leader. Because one resolution said that defence co- operation with Indonesia would cease unless Indonesia changed its position on Timor, the Foreign Minister felt his first duty was to tax Australia's relationship with Indonesia with this issue. He got a flea in his ear. It could have been worse, but his skills avoided the worst results from this mistaken venture. Then followed a further expedition to sell the conference resolutions on Vietnam. This effort brings us to the present predicament of the Government. After an initial try-on, the idea of offering foreign aid to Vietnam has been put to one side.

The Prime Minister, according to the Press, stimulated an emphasis on approaching Hanoi directly on the issue of Vietnamese occupation of Kampuchea. This was in the apparent belief that the Vietnamese would offer enough public cause to give credibility to the Australian initiative, sufficient to get the Government through a series of forthcoming Labor Party conferences, where the left-wing tail is thought to be wagging vigorously. These party demands have made impossible a quiet diplomacy which the issues require. But the sudden presumption by the Deputy Prime Minister that settlement was so close at hand as to introduce the complex subject of peacekeeping was an unexpected contribution. It was unexpected to everybody, particularly the members of his own party. It was complicating in every way. All of this, of course, is unwanted in the face of the two weeks of difficulty caused by Ministers poking their noses into other Minister's business. One recalls Senator Button's intervention on the Australian Broadcasting Commission issue; a failure of Ministers to handle, in an elementary, discreet way, a national security issue; in all a fundamental failure of Ministers to curb their tongues and act as members of a responsible government. All of this gives a disturbing picture, both nationally and internationally.

In early June, the Prime Minister leaves for overseas on a mission to explain our foreign policy. His mission is now complicated by the disarray manifest in the Government's diplomacy. It is complicated by his Ministers' misunderstanding of it and the interpretation being accorded by international observers to the remarks of his Ministers. His absence raises the question: Who will be Australia 's Acting Prime Minister while he is away. Will it be the adept Foreign Minister or the impulsive Deputy Prime Minister? I hope this damaging excursion into international affairs proves instructive to the Deputy Prime Minister. He should now cease to torture his mind with conspiracy theories as advanced in Bathurst against Dame Leonie Kramer and the John Fairfax organisation. He should cease to blame others for the public predicament currently faced by his Government and instead he should get on with the task of governing. In the final analysis, the problems are problems of management. Bad management and bad relationships between Ministers have inflicted grievous wounds on the public's confidence in this particular Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the initiation of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) into foreign affairs. He is a much travelled Minister, as we know. I have not travelled as much as he has, but I think I have come out of it a little better. Let us talk about professionalism in this area. Admittedly I made a statement during the weekend which spoke about Australia's initiatives in foreign affairs. I want to make the point that in the course of making that statement perhaps I made too vicious an attack on John Fairfax and Sons Ltd. That was the real issue. I started to ask why it was that a proprietary group which owns so many newspapers was so bereft of concern for Australia's standing in the world that it allowed to be published a whole series of classified material without looking at the damage it had done to Australia's image. I mentioned the protest notes that I had received as a result of that publication and I mentioned also the fact that across the world our ambassadors had done nothing but send us cables saying that it appeared that the Government was unable to maintain its secrecy, its efficiency and its intelligence services. What an indictment of that paper. So okay, I will accept the blast that I get now, that in the course of mentioning a number of other initiatives, I dared mention Japan. Would it have been all right if I had mentioned India?
—It depends what you said about it.

—Yes, it depends what I said. The honourable member was not even there. We will have a look at what I said. I said this, and I will say it calmly , that I met Son Sann during the week and, as honourable members well know, he is the leader of one of the coalition groups opposing the Vietnamese. Not one word was mentioned by the honourable member about the meeting with Son Sann or his visit here. I spent an hour with the honourable gentleman. I was very impressed with his sincerity because he made that sincerity very clear to me. I have been in the refugee camps of Kampuchea and I have been in Hanoi twice. I have spoken to the Japanese on more than one occasion and I will not accept the view that the professional advice I receive is somewhere outside those limits.
—How would you know; you have not asked for it.

—If the honourable member would just listen, I will tell him the position. I spoke to Son Sann about the position. The Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden) who, as the honourable member knows, is a good friend of mine, said: 'I am going to Hanoi and I will be putting propositions to Hanoi very soon'. I asked Son Sann what he thought of the concepts that the Australian Labor Party had in mind. He said that he was more concerned at this stage in getting aid for his forces. That was his position and I respect it. I said: 'Look, the issue has got to be on the question of trying to get a settlement in that region and there must be a withdrawal of Vietnamese forces. Have you any objection to our talking about that?' 'Not at all', said Son Sann, 'I welcome it. It is the only hope my people have got'. What an indictment of the people opposite to think that that man is able to say that, because he is talking about a peaceful solution without this rather difficult proposition of bringing Vietnam to its knees. The message is that Vietnam is economically stronger than ever. It has occupied that territory and we have to do something about peaceful negotiation. For the benefit of the honourable gentleman opposite, I should like to place on record a letter which I received this day from Son Sann. I refer to only a segment of it. He thanks me for the interview, and says:

SPEECH.PARA: We trust Australia will endeavour to find a peaceful settlement to the Cambodian conflict--
I might add that he always refers to the area as Cambodia. He continues:
We do not seek to hinder any such move.

This is the position. The move will be made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in the normal course of making diplomatic moves. He will put that Australia suggests that there be removal of the forces of Vietnam. I can tell honourable members, with regard to this professionalism that they think I lack, that I met Thach in 1980 in Hanoi. I spoke to Thach, the Foreign Minister of Vietnam, about the problems that I saw there. He said this: 'I am not going to withdraw from Kampuchea until such time as Pol Pot is disarmed'. I said: 'That is a no win situation. It is the chicken and the egg. Could there not be some prospect of some suggestion of a United Nations peacekeeping force?' He said: 'That is a matter of consideration, but I am not going to be in the position of being attacked by China from the north and west at the same time. I ask honourable members to bear in mind that there had been a surgical strike with massive casualties.

The honourable member talks about professionalism. Massive casualties were suffered in 1979. Because his Government had refused or virtually discounted aid to Vietnam-I can understand that position-it meant that our Ambassador had no influence at all in Hanoi. The distinguished professional advice that I might get was not able to even cover the people I was able to meet and the honourable member talks about professionalism. At that stage, of course, Son Sann was not known to me. But I had been to all the refugee camps and I had spoken to all the refugees and their consideration was: 'Can we not get peace in our country; but we cannot go back under Pol Pot, this genocidal maniac who has slaughtered 3 million of our people.' This included two Australians. All through that time the Opposition recognised that regime. It recognised it all that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —You initially recognised it.

—Yes, but that was in 1975. The genocide had not taken place then. Let us be honest about it. The present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) had to get out of the Cabinet, he was so horrified. Let us have a look at the Labor Party's policy in this area, for which I claim credit. It says this -
—Tell us about the Japanese.
—The honourable member never mentioned them at all.
—I did.
—He seems to hate the thought that I even mentioned them. The Labor policy on Indo-China states:

SPEECH.PARA: The general abhorrence in Australia of the Democratic Kampuchean regime should be kept in mind when considerating Australia's attitude towards the region. Australia should discourage all support for the Democratic Kampuchea (Pol Pot) regime so as to create conditions favourable to a withdrawal of Vietnamese forces. Australia should also continue to lend its support to international efforts aimed at decreasing regional tensions.

I claim credit for that. That is our party policy. When I was spokesman for the Opposition, how many times did I mention the matter that is so upsetting at the present time. It will be found in all my speeches made in this Parliament, or many of them, that on every occasion I spoke about initiative and on many occasions I spoke about the intiative being with Japan. There is no surprise. Honourable members will see that on every occasion that I had a chance to talk about solving the problems of Kampuchea I mentioned this matter. It goes against the grain to have it suggested to me that this was the first time that I had mentioned the matter.

I assure the honourable member for Warringah that it is not news to me that this matter was mentioned. I mentioned co-operation with Japan on five occasions in debates in this Parliament between 1980 and 1982. DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT (ELECTION BLACKOUT) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-
—Why can't I listen to the Minister?

—If the honourable member is patient it will all come in good time. The purpose of the amendment to the Broadcasting and Television Act, which the Government has moved, is to lift partially the ban during an election period on the electronic media-that is, to lift the ban which presently exists between midnight on the Wednesday to the close of the poll on the Saturday. Under the Government's proposal news and commentary about the election will be permitted on the electronic media but advertising will not be permitted during the last three days of the election campaign. The history of the pre-polling day electronic blackout began in 1942 when a committee recommended to the then Federal Labor Government that a law applying at that time, I understand in Canada, also apply in Australia. The Government accepted the recommendation for the ban which, at that stage, was radio only and hence the ban began. In 1949 a State Labor Government in New South Wales passed legislation, which has since been repealed, for an identical blackout on Press coverage during the last three days of an election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1954 the Royal Commission on Television recommended that the radio ban be extended to include television. In 1969 an amendment to the Broadcasting and Television Act allowed the electronic media outside the area covered by that media to continue to broadcast during a by-election campaign for the final three days of the campaign. It is interesting to note that the electronic ban has never applied to elections in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. By 1979 breaches of this ban were becoming apparent both in the Parliament and outside in the electronic media. The then Minister for Post and Telecommunications, the Hon. Tony Staley, indicated that in his view the law needed examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Examination?

—One would say examination and review. My understanding is that during the 1980 Federal election campaign all the leaders of the major parties, with the exception of the Australian Democrats-that is, the Liberal Party, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party-were in favour of the ban continuing. It is my understanding that at that time the official ALP policy was that the ban would not be lifted until the introduction of public funding of elections which, to my way of thinking, indicates that it was the view of the Labor Party that when it was time to lift the ban on the electronic media, with the introduction of public funding, it would be lifted in its entirety because it makes sense only if public funding were to assist with that advertising. My source for the points I have been making is the Parliamentary Library Research Service.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1981 the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters put forward a compormise proposal to try to break the deadlock that had existed for so many years. It had become apparent that there were differences within the parties on each side of the House as to whether or not the ban should continue. The FARB compromise proposal was that news and comment should be permitted for the last days of a campaign but not advertising. Early in 1982 Senator Macklin, a member of the Australian Democrats, introduced in the Senate a private member's Bill which had the intent of lifting the ban in its entirety on all the electronic media. In the last paragraph of his second reading speech Senator Macklin said:

The electronic blackout must be removed. It is a democratic right for all Australian citizens to have access to all information from all sources. It is time this absurd and regressive ban was removed. This Bill will dispose of it in its entirety.
So it is obvious that the Australian Democrats believe that the electronic ban on advertising, news and commentary should be lifted completely.

Information provided by the Parliamentary Library Research Service indicates that the Australian Labor Party at its July 1982 conference appeared to have adopted or accepted the FARB compromise proposal of news and comment but no advertising and this is faithfully shown in the Bill now before the House. As I said, as the debate on this issue has raged over the years, leading politicans on both sides of the House have changed their positions and attitudes and there have been differences and swings in the numbers for and against within the parties. There are many in the Opposition today who doubt that the lifting of the ban, either in the form set out in the Government Bill or in the amendment that we will be proposing at the Committee stage-that is to lift the ban completely on news, comment and advertising-is the correct position to adopt. Therefore, they will be closely watching the position. A number of honourable members on both sides of this chamber will be closely watching what happens once the ban is lifted following passage of the legislation, either in the form proposed by the Government or in the form that we propose.

The view of the majority of members of the coalition in the Opposition is very much that if the ban on news, comment and advertising is to be lifted, it should be lifted completely. The reason for this is, firstly, that if there is to be an equitable arrangement or comparision between the electronic media and the print media, if each is to be given an equal position of complete freedom, the ban must be lifted completely. At the moment print media advertising as well as news commentary is permitted right through to the close of the poll. It is argued that the ban on the electronic media should not be lifted because a breathing space should be provided for people in the last couple of days before the poll. However, we will not get a breathing space if news and comment are permitted. So the breathing space argument is a farce. There is no argument that allows or justifies the transmitting or televising of news and comment but still bars advertising being permitted at the same time. One can also question the basic assumption that a breathing space is required anyway in the sense that one can avoid physically opening a newspaper but the electronic media is beamed at one. I think that we have lived with the electronic media for long enough that people can turn off physically and mentally in the same way as they turn off in respect of the print media, if that is their desire.

But an additional problem arises if news and comment is permitted but not advertising. There is no provision in the Broadcasting and Television Act for right of reply to a candidate or party subjected to attack in the last few days of a campaign. Section 116 (3) of the Broadcasting and Television Act states:

If, during an election period, a licensee broadcasts or televises election matter, he shall afford reasonable opportunities for the broadcasting or televising of election matter to all political parties contesting the election, being parties which were represented in either House of the parliament for which the election is to be held at the time of its last meeting before the election period.

That section of the Act contains two key points. The first concerns reasonable opportunity. Reasonable opportunity does not mean equal opportunity. There has been debate over the years as to whether or not the Act should specify equal opportunity. The second key point is that reasonable opportunity is to be calculated over the whole election period. The election period is from the time that the writs are issued until either the close of the poll or the blackout late on Wednesday night befor the poll. The point is that a station licensee could say quite justifiably that if one considers reasonable opportunity over the whole election period candidate A or political party A has been given a fair run, a reasonable opportunity, and there is no requirement to force the station to provide a right of reply to that person or that party which has been maligned or has been the subject of an attack in the last couple of days. However, even if advertising is allowed there is still an opportunity to buy time if time is not given. I can assure the House that this has occurred in the past. It has happened to me personally. The opportunity for one to reply even in the last couple of days before the ban applied on Wednesday night was still restricted in the way that I have mentioned. One still had the rights to advertise, of course; to try to reply by buying time on radio or television even when the opportunity is rejected by the station itself. The Opposition believes that if we are to have an equitable, comparable and logical arrangement for the electronic media in the period leading up to the polling day we have to lift completely the ban on news, comment and advertising.

I suppose the final point I want to make about the attitude of the Opposition in this matter is that other countries have lifted their restrictions on the electronic media in the last couple of days before a poll. I think one or two countries might have some restrictions in respect of the polling day itself but that is about all.

It will be of considerable interest to the House, and certainly to the Opposition, to see what the Australian Democrats do in the Senate. As I said earlier, the Australian Democrats introduced a private member's Bill and they have publicly committed themselves, over several elections, to lift completely the ban on the electronic media. If they are to maintain their position and their credibility on this issue, obviously they will have to support our amendment in the Senate. It will be very interesting to see whether the Australian Democrats maintain their stated position. The Opposition will not be opposing the second reading of this Bill. We will be moving an amendment at the Committee stage to remove all restrictions on the electronic media during an election period.

SPEECH.PARA: Broadcasters are quite unanimous now. The Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters has put out a proposal to which the honourable member for Murray ( Mr Lloyd) has referred. It is more or less that adopted by the Government. The proposal was endorsed with varying qualifications by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia, Mr Ranald McDonald, of the International Press Institute, the Australian Newspapers Council, the Australian Journalists Association, the Rupert Public Interest Movement Inc., the Media Studies Department at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, and distinguished academics such as Professor Henry Mayer and Dr Patricia Edgar. Might I say with due humility that some years ago I wrote a few articles myself denouncing this monstrous blackout. In the years since I have qualified my views a little because-this is the heart of the issue-the problem involves or is claimed to involve a balance, the desirable and difficult to achieve balance between freedom for broadcasters and the public interest.

I think we should emphasise the public interest, because no one has asked the public what its view of the blackout is. Broadcasters, who tend to be pretty elitist people, claim they know that the public hates the blackout. But no one has asked the public and no one has taken a poll. From my researches in the library and elsewhere I can find no evidence of any pollster having asked the public what it thinks about the blackout. Of course, the public interest was said to be served by the existing law. This Government, with the support of the Opposition, intends to change that law. The public interest is served in two well-known and familiar ways. The two-day blackout gave a welcome break. I can only give anecdotal evidence. So many people have said at many elections over many years: 'Thank goodness it is Wednesday night. Tonight will be the last of all the propaganda and we will have a couple of days of peace'. It is a common attitude but I do not know whether it is as widespread as some people might think because it has never been tested. We do not know. It is certainly a welcome break to some people. The broadcasters who say that the public really wants the blackout removed could establish that very easily with the great resources available to them by having a few polls. They might well establish their point in that way. What I am saying is that at this stage we do not know.

Another point is that the blackout prevents last minute deceptions. I think we have all had experience of them. I had one experience which, in perspective, was quite amusing. Before the by-election at which I was elected to this House a couple of years ago, at the eleventh hour as it were, on the Wednesday night there was a very extended segment in one news program which said that I could not stand as a candidate because my resignation as Administrator of Norfolk Island had not been gazetted; and therefore, I could not stand for Parliament and the people who were supporting me should reconsider because even if I nominally won the election I would have to be disqualified. There was a bit of a carfuffle among people who were working for my cause. The matter was given a great deal of air time. It was given a certain amount of space in the press next day. At least I did have a couple of days to point out the absolute folly and foolishnes of that eleventh hour deception which occurred on the Wednesday. That is something which happened to me. I am sure that over the years there have been more significant occurrences, as other members would know. If the blackout does not take place on Wednesday then at least if last minute deceptions arise the person involved has the Thursday and Friday to correct them. Of course, everyone sees the strength of the broadcasters' case.

Weight should be given to the public interest argument in favour of the welcome break and the argument in favour of the prevention of last minute deceptions. There is a balance between the two arguments. It has been decided by the Government, with the support of the Opposition, that the tilt in this balance is now to go in the direction of freedom of the broadcasters. However, I do agree with the honourable member for Murray that if we are to tilt in the direction of freedom for the broadcasters we should do it properly. If we argue that the community is so mature and its handling of the electronic media is sufficiently sensible that commentary should be free, how on earth can the Government justify saying that political advertising should not also be allowed in the same couple of days, the Thursday and the Friday, before voting day?

I also cannot see the hard and fast distinction between commentary and paid advertising. A good deal of commentary that I have heard on the media seems to be very similar to paid advertising in its prejudice. There is very little distinction at all. I cannot see the justification for distinguishing them on that ground either. But there is another consideration: In a situation where the commentators are unfair-this could apply to any political party at particular times when commentators tend to be unanimously unfair, and such situations have occurred-there is no way of getting the matter corrected on the electronic media except by advertising. I think that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) ought to take this into account. If a political candidate or political party has the right to advertise in the last couple of days before an election, and not only commentators have the right to comment, the chances are that last minute deceptions or last minute examples of bias or unfairness could be corrected by advertising. I think that consideration should be taken into account.

When this legislation is passed the ABC will have a certain advantage because it does not, in any case, carry advertising. It is receiving a complete and unqualified bonus. It will be able to broadcast commentaries. It does not have to worry about the restriction on advertisers because that does not involve it. I wish to remind the House that under the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill, which is still before the Parliament, ABC staff dealing with complaints are not and will not be permitted to receive complaints about bias and unfairness, only about inaccuracy or invasion of privacy. Last minute commentaries could be biased and unfair but nothing can be done about them. I think the political interest should have the right to advertise on the commercial channels to correct bias or unfairness, whether it be on the ABC or on a commercial channel. But the basic philosophic point is that if we are going to act on the assumption that the community has the right to hear free commentaries, there is no distinction that justifies not allowing parties to have the right to have paid advertising in the same period. I welcome the final abolition of the blackout but consider that the Government does not go far enough. The distinction on which the Government bases its amendments to the Act cannot be justified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very good to see that there is a wide degree of consensus between the Government and the Opposition on this most important piece of legislation. One matter on which we have not yet reached consensus, of course, is the question of paid political advertising. I would like to address some remarks to that in a moment. It is important to understand- the community should understand this-that this particular proposal does have a wide degree of support. Previous speakers in this debate have canvassed that support. I do not think it is necessary for me to go through the points raised at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important for me to speak briefly about the sort of support for this legislation which exists in my electorate of Stirling in Western Australia. I in fact have two commercial televisions stations in my electorate-TVW7 and STW9. I know that the current arrangements for election blackouts inconvenience them substantially in the days immediately prior to an election. Additionally, we now have two very good public affairs radio stations-6PR and 6KY. With the frequency of by-elections and the overlapping State and Federal elections a good deal of inconvenience is caused to them in the conduct of sound public affairs radio. This move certainly will advantage the two television stations and the two radio stations I have mentioned.

I wish also to refer to a matter that was raised earlier. It requires a good deal of judgment by the broadcasters and, to some extent, places a great burden on them that if they transgress the current election blackout provisions they will face penalties. Quite obviously that hampers the activities of broadcasters . They have to decide what they should put in and what they should leave out of their news bulletins. Extraordinary situations can occur. For example, a by- election may be held in Western Australia and a major event involving the Federal Labor Government could occur. During the period of the by-election the people of Western Australia would not have access to that news. That is an extraordinary situation. It really means that a situation can arise in which people are denied the right to information. Many of those instances have occured in recent times.

The community at large is more interested in the actitivies taking place in the political arena. It is also wrong of us to try to curb, in some way, their involvement and interest. How do we come to a clarification of the public interest? Our view of the broadcasting media is such that we believe a fairly full and free disclosure of events is important. This chamber is one forum in which those events can be disclosed, but we also support the notion than in the wider community the electronic media have the same right to a fairly free and full disclosure.

I am pleased that the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) has already addressed himself to that matter. I know that he has long had an interest in that approach to the media. However, we must also deal with this question of last minute deceptions. How are we to deal with the fact that such deceptions may be practised in election campaigns? It is probably fairly important to recognise in this forum that the political arena does throw up last minute deceptions. I am sure that honourable members opposite are familiar with some that they may have been a party to or aware of over time. It is quite important that we address ourselves to that aspect. Can we therefore redress those last minute deceptions by the use of advertising? We did witness a last minute sensation, reported in the Melbourne Age, concerning the Flinders by-election. It might well be argued from this side of the House that that caused our candidate some disadvantage. Can advertising correct such a disadvantage? I suggest that exactly the opposite is true, that it cannot.

What we have to establish about advertising-I believe that honourable members opposite are much more familiar with it than we are because they usually have more dollars with which to buy it-is that to some extent it does bend people's perceptions. It tries to take an image and present it in a way that does not necessarily inform the public. In the recent Federal elections, in which many of us were fortunate to be involved-I might say successfully-there was a major attempt by some in the then Government to spend a large amount on advertising in the last two or three days of the campaign. Fortunately the electorate is more discerning than that and because of its overall ability to realise the economic circumstances of the day the last minute attempt to change people's perceptions was not effective.

We on this side of the House believe that advertising ought not to be permitted in the last few days of a campaign. We would be quite willing to allow the public affairs commentators and the news teams at the various radio and television networks to do their jobs but we believe that since experience has shown that advertising is involved in bending people's perceptions and in changing their judgments, particularly as honourable members opposite, I repeat, often have a larger bank balance with which to pay for election advertising, we ought not to agree to a situation in which people can have their views on politics distorted at the last minute, in those last few days, that in fact it would be well to protect the electorate from that sort of assault. We saw that sort of assault take place in the last elections. Many people in the electorate said to me that they were very glad that those kinds of advertisements were terminated on the Wednesday. But I do believe that if we have a very comprehensive electronic media-the evidence is that we do-it is very important that we give them the opportunity to develop their stories and analyses of news up to the last minute. At the moment they are severely handicapped by the restriction, but I believe this measure will do much to remove their burden. As I said earlier, with particular respect to the two television stations in the electorate of Stirling, plus the development of public affairs radio in Perth, the passage of this measure would be of considerable advantage.

I conclude by saying that if there is one thing that we have to establish as a government, it is that the more people have a right, and free access, to information the better will be the kind of government that we can offer. Certainly, this measure should go a long way towards achieving that goal.
Debate (on motion by Mr Duffy) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Small Business: Economic Planning Advisory Council-Nuclear Arms-Australian Film Industry-Consumer Price Index-Death of Mr R. Fazackerley-Museum of Australia

PROCTEXT.PARA: Small Business: Economic Planning Advisory Council-Nuclear Arms-Australian Film Industry-Consumer Price Index-Death of Mr R. Fazackerley-Museum of Australia

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I raise the question of small business representation on the proposed Economic Planning Advisory Council known as EPAC. The Government does not propose to have any small business representation on this body. The Council, we are told, is intended to continue the process of consultation and information exchange begun at the National Economic Summit Conference.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has decided to end the practice of holding formal pre-Budget consultations with major community business and employee organisations. Business groups now have to deal with an authority, rather than with the Government itself. This is not an adequate replacement for pre-Budget discussions with approximately 40 organisations representing many and various community points of view. Under the Australian Labor Party's proposals there will be less communication and consultation rather than more. The EPAC filter will act as a blockage to community views reaching the Government. It will stop the Government hearing what the community thinks. Small business will be further removed than ever from the Government. The Economic Planning Advisory Council is bureaucratic and, with its limited membership, it will not be a useful consultative body in a Budget context.

Only one small business organisation, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, known as COSBOA, was represented at the Summit, and not one small businessman was invited, in spite of the fact that there were present 28 representatives of big business. Small businessmen and women were ignored-they were excluded from the Summit, excluded from consultation and consensus. At the Summit, the Government did not allow any discussion of the particular needs of small business following the address of Mr Gibbons of COSBOA . The Government deliberately did not allow the Summit to consider the question of the need and problems facing small business in the community today. It obviously is not interested in the needs and problems facing them. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) obviously prefers the company of big business tycoons rather than representatives of the most dynamic sector of the Australian economy-the small businessman.

We are told that EPAC is to be the main vehicle of the process of co-operation and consultation, and that it will eventually participate in 'broad indicative planning'. I ask the Government: How is small business going to be 'indicatively planned'? What does the Government mean? Does it intend to direct and control the direction of small business? It is stated that EPAC will be a forum for consultation and communication, but there will not be any small business representation; small business will be ignored.

The Economic Planning Advisory Council is to be a statutory authority with its own charter and it will be chaired by the Prime Minister. Its charter should refer to the importance of small business in the Australian economy. I urge the Government to recognise the importance of small businesses to the Australian economy in this way. Even if the Government gives such a commitment, I am not confident that it will be of assistance to small business. However, given the existence of EPAC, it must take into account the needs, difficulties and problems of small business.

As I have said, I do not believe that EPAC will function effectively as a consltative body and one cannot be optimistic that it will understand or be sympathetic to the views of small businessmen. We are also told that 'balanced representation might require three to four representatives from each of union and business'. I call on the Government to have representatives of small business on EPAC. If EPAC is, as the Government says, to be representative of a wide range of views, small business must be included and represented.

This Labor Government-the Hawke Government-is again failing to understand the nature and importance of the small business sector in the Australian economy. This is in contrast to the position of the Opposition. As its leader, the honourable member for Kooyong, Andrew Peacock, has said:
The Liberal Party has recognised the importance of small business as a priority area and its crucial role in ensuring Australia's recovery from the recession.
The voice of small business must be heard. I call on the Government to have small businessmen represented on EPAC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond briefly to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) by reminding him that small businesses achieved their highest level of bankruptcy in Australian history under the regime of his Government. I also point out to him that the National Economic Summit Conference is in addition to the consultative mechanisms that Australia has experienced. The various small business groups and others he mentioned that want to consult with the Australian Government are most welcome to do so, and indeed did do so while we were in Opposition, through many avenues other than the one he suggests, which is a small coterie of Cabinet Ministers. We are happy to accept them in our day to day contacts as individuals. Ministers have been very open in making their time available to representative groups. Above all, our policy committees have on many occasions entertained representations from various delegations.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise a matter which is, perhaps, the most important of all to this Federal Government in the long term, because it is of importance to every citizen of the world. If we do not solve this problem, we can forget all the others, because it threatens the extinction of all higher species. It is the matter of nuclear war and the alternatives to it. The history of war has shown that as we get new types of strategic capacity as high technology evolves, we eventually render obsolete the existing political structures. Some tribes could defend themselves with palisades, like the stakes around the Polynesian village in New Zealand; they had to defend themselves against spears and arrows and the like. Then, when firearms came along, tribes had to have something more substantial, such as castles. When cannon and the dreadnoughts became the order of the day, castles became obsolete. Instead of having baronetcies and principalities, we had to move to larger nations and empires. But now they have become obsolete.

We have weapons that can destroy half the world, perhaps the whole world, in a matter of half an hour or an hour, not only in the way that we have seen in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, but also in destroying the ozone layer, which, on a conservative estimate, would increase ultra-violet radiation two and a half times-enough to blind virtually everything with eyes, unless special precautions were taken-and so wipe out most of the higher animals that might escape all the other deadly results of such an all-out war.

There have been many initiatives to set up an alternative. Of those organisations that I was privileged to visit and consult last year, on my trip to the United Nations and thereabouts, the one that I particularly want to mention, in the minute or so available to me, is War Control Planners Incorporated. It was founded by a United States Air Force retired lieutenant- colonel. He has had extensive experience as a pioneer in aviation and in flight control mechanisms. He has pointed out the potential to use satellites to bring information to all citizens of the world, on a real time basis, to divert the high technology and the leading brains and researchers in science and technology , who are mostly at present concerned in devising better methods of construction , into constructive co-operative methods of surveying where our industry is going and where armament and disarmament are going, and to act as a practical and concrete demonstration that an international authority can enforce world law , settle disputes between nations and divert the waste of the arms race into constructive projects. There are many other organisations, about which I shall speak at a later date.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to talk about one of our great industries, an industry which has never received adequate recognition. I do so on a bipartisan basis. I refer to the Australian film industry. Prior to the recent election, the then Government indicated that it would extend tax deductibility to include films which were completed within two years and would allow 150 per cent tax deductibility at the point of investment. The Government decision was accepted by the then Opposition spokesman in this area, Senator Susan Ryan, and after the election the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) indicated that that concession would be granted.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the disappointing thing is that at this late stage of the financial year no legislation to that effect has been introduced into the House. I appeal to the Government to introduce such legislation as a matter of urgency and to seek the Opposition's co-operation to ensure that it has a speedy passage in not only this House but also the Senate because, frankly, time is running out.

We have a great film industry, which produces at least $40m worth of work each year. It is an industry which is based on the feature film industry, documentaries and the animated section. But as with many things, its great problem is lack of finance. The finance has not been forthcoming, notwithstanding the quality of Australian films, because investors have lost confidence. They need this legislation to ensure that the films that are waiting to be produced actually come on to the screen. It always disappoints me when we find in Australia that in matters of culture generally, we tend to undersell ourselves. We do not appear to be like so many other nations and get out and about and tell people about the peculiar qualities of Australian culture, which, in effect, is an honest culture because it reflects adequately and accurately Australian society. It reflects the fact that we have a particularly Australian rugged culture, a dependence and an outlook which indicates a concern for other people.

To my mind, films in Australia should continue to have significant Australian content, because we have things to be proud of. In all areas of film production, we have people whom we might term prophets who are not unknown except in our own country. I should like to talk briefly about some of these people. We have come a long way since the early days of film production in this country. I have as a constituent of mine in Toowoomba a marvellous Australian person, Mrs Elsa Chauvel. She and the late Charles Chauvel were the pioneers in the development of Australian film production. Now we have continuation, people who have built on that wonderful foundation that these pioneers gave us.

The film The Man from Snowy River netted for its producers over $9m and has been accepted overseas. Such films indicate the quality of our producers. We have people such as Pat Lovell, who not only produces films-the film Monkey Grip had a specific showing of Australian life-but also contributes as a member of the Australian Film Commission. We have directors of whom we can be proud, including Peter Weir. He was associated with The Year of Living Dangerously, which I understand was highly regarded at the annual Cannes film festival. We have great Australian script writers such as David Williamson, who is well known as a play-writer. We have good people in cinematography. Those who have seen The Man from Snowy River will appreciate the wonderful scenery that was filmed. But above all we have the sheer quality of Australian actors and actresses, such as Helen Morse, in Far East.

Because of their close association with the theatre, these people know what it is like to work with other people, and they reflect this concern and expertise on the screen. Who will ever forget Angela Punch MacGregor's display in that typical Australian film We of the Never Never?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the adjournment, there is one particular matter that concerns me. It results from the previous Government's occupancy of the Treasury benches and concerns the consumer price index. It will be noticed that we have given a fair degree of attention to the establishment of a centralised wage fixing system and, ultimately, we will be working towards a situation in which we will try to measure wages against the consumer price index . Under the previous Government, centralised wage indexation ceased in July 1981 . If we were to restore the system of wage indexation it would require us again tying wages to the consumer price index. It may well be that at some future date this Government might look at that question. I think it is important to put on record, however, that the consumer price index, as a method of measuring the increases in the cost of living of the average family, is quite ineffective in many respects. Let me talk specifically about what happened last year.

SPEECH.PARA: In July 1982 the Federal Government announced the review that it had conducted of the consumer price index. It pointed out that in fact this review had looked at a number of areas of expenditure to see how representative the consumer price index is of the normal cost of living of the average Australian household. I should add also that the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, whose members actually work in the Australian Bureau of Statistics, told me at the time that it felt that its members were quite understaffed when it came to doing that review and as a consequence the review was quite ineffective. This is also pointed out in the document that the Bureau put out, and which the then Treasurer tabled, which spoke about the consumer price index.

Let me speak for just a moment about the items of expenditure that are excluded from the consumer price index. Those particular items, for example, are household mortgage interest, consumer credit charges, land purchased for housing , watches and jewellery, subscriptons to clubs and trade unions, veterinary services, legal services, optical services and gambling. Those items of expenditure have been excluded from the measurement of the consumer price index. I see that the former Treasurer is in the House. I acknowledge that it is very difficult to include every item within a consumer price index but I think that there are a couple of items in this regimen which deserve inclusion. I will focus attention for a moment on housing mortgage interest. Quite obviously, considering the pattern of interest rates in recent years-I am not trying to apportion blame between the previous Government and ourselves-this particular area of household expenditure has become quite severe. Many electors in Australia have had that as one of their major cost items in their regular weekly or monthly budget. To leave that item out of the consumer index is to leave out a quite substantial element and it is one that I believe we, as a government, ought to look at with respect to making the regimen more representative.

Another item, of course, is the question of consumer credit charges. With the rate of inflation as it has been and with the access to credit becoming more and more important for people in this community, it is important to understand that within the fabric of people's household expenditure, again those kinds of consumer credit charges are quite important in the context of ordinary expenditure. If we are to keep faith with the union movement and with the wider community it is important that we as a government look at including that item in the regimen in any future review. Again acknowledging the process as it developed, if we recognise that the Australian Bureau of Statistics complained that it did not have the resources to complete the review thoroughly, due to staff ceilings and so on, and also the complaints of the ACOA at the time that it felt it could not conduct the review completely, I think it is important to say this in a spirit of consensus. I am not here to say what a terrible thing it is that the previous Government left these items out, but rather to say that these are items that it should have included and it is something that we ought to pay attention to.

I might just conclude by commenting that some of the other items in the regimen are also important. One item that was included in the consumer price index, incidentally, was the cost of overseas travel. One wonders why a measure of Australian travel was not also included. Let us be a little realistic about it. Obviously, overseas travel is something that people on higher incomes have access to. Let us see whether we can include domestic travel in the consumer price index so as to also provide a more effective recognition of costs in the average household.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to pay a tribute in the national Parliament to a very great Tasmanian who passed away last Saturday. I refer to Mr Reginald Fazackerley, who was born in 1893 and who was, without doubt, one of the best known and highly regarded boatbuilders ever to come out of Australia's maritime State. I want to refer to his long and distinguished career. As you will note, Mr Speaker, he died at the age of 90 years. I think there would be many honourable members in this House who would either know of some of his work or, indeed, there may be some honourable members in this House who were actually involved with some of the vessels which he built during his career.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fazackerley left school at the age of 11 years and built his first boat at the age of 16 years. That was in 1909. He was particularly expert in the building of small boats and dinghys and in the use of huon pine and King Billy pine. He had a very long and distinguished career as a boatbuilder but also had been very much involved in motor vehicles and was a top-notch motor mechanic. He was a very great sportsman. He became involved in cycling. He also started in Tasmania-in Hobart, in fact-a roller skating rink and he owned a gymnasium.

During World War II he was drafted to the Commonwealth as a shipbuilder at the Prince of Wales Bay shipyard and it was in that period that he built many of the lifeboats and small hospital ships which were used in Papua New Guinea. It has been said to me that probably many hundreds if not thousands of Australian servicemen owe their lives to those little boats which were built in Hobart, Tasmania, by Mr Reg Fazackerley and the staff he had working under him. He then worked for the Hobart Marine Board as a full time foreman and when he retired he took up work again as a full time boatbuilder.

It is one of my most pleasant memories that as a very small boy I sold tickets at the Sandy Bay regatta raffling huon pine dinghies. Those tickets were sold at one shilling each. The dinghies in those days were valued at about #50. Today such a dinghy would be worth several thousand dollars. To give Parliament an idea, a huon pine suite, that is table and chairs-at one stage one was proposed for the Lodge; the new occupant might be very interested in having some genuine Tasmanian timber in the Lodge, some beautiful huon pine-would be valued at over $8,000. Reg Fazackerley made a number of boats which he then donated to charities, regatta associations and the like.

I do not frequently in this House pay a tribute by way of an obituary to a person who has passed from the scene. But I think I am speaking on behalf of thousands of Tasmanians and many people in other parts of Australia in paying tribute to this man who was a great craftsman, a person who loved the water, a person who was a master in working with timber, and, as I said, during a long and distinguished career made hundreds of dinghies and vessels which were used both for pleasure and at times for national defence, particular in 1942.

Mr Fazackerley lived at Duke Street, Sandy Bay, right in the heart of the Federal electorate of Denison. He was well known and widely respected and with his passing Tasmania loses a very great son, one of whom it could be truly said: He made it and he made it in Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak in support of a proposal which would be of great benefit to the Australian Capital Territory and to Australia. I refer to the proposal to build a Museum of Australia. The Museum would be an Australian museum representing and researching many aspects of Australia's culture. It is not to be a museum of international culture. The collections will be based on three primary themes-Aboriginal culture, European settlement and the natural environment of Australia. The collection would be housed both indoors and outdoors and, as it would be necessary to have botanic and zoological displays, it would therefore be necessary to have a fairly large area.

SPEECH.PARA: A site of roughly 80 hectares, 200 acres, is proposed for the Museum. It is located at Yarramundi Reach on the foreshores of Lake Burley Griffin, just five minutes from the centre of Canberra. This project would not only be of great benefit to all Australians but be of particular importance for Canberra as an employment generation project. The project would provide significant employment for the construction industry at a time when employment on the new Parliament House project and the Australian Defence Academy will have peaked and be declining. A project of this scale and importance would probably generate employment in the building industry for about 200 construction workers for four to five years. That is very significant for members of the construction industry in Canberra.

I have made the point consistently in this House about the need for the long term planning of Canberra's development. The Museum of Australia will be particularly important because when we peak with the building of the new Parliament House there will be employment for our skilled workers. Once the building is completed it will have a very beneficial effect on the local economy . On completion the Museum will provide new and continuing employment for skilled and semi-skilled people. It will be a major addition to the tourist industry of the Australian Capital Territory and the south west region of New South Wales. It will, of course, have very significant multiplier effects. If we can get a tourist to stay for an additional night in Canberra it will add an additional $50m annually to Canberra's economy. This means that in one year we will recoup the estimated capital cost of the project, namely $50m. The project is planned for completion by about 1990. So a considerable amount of expenditure is not needed at the moment. But the most important aspect is that a commitment is made to this project and that some money is made available in the next financial year to ensure that planning projects are under way. In that way it will be completed in very good time to take on many of the construction workers from the new Parliament House. It will add significantly to the tourist industry . Although it is a significant capital works project amounting to $50m, that amount of money can be recouped, as I said, in just one year by adding an additional one night's stay for every tourist who comes to Canberra. There has been a great deal of discussion about diversifying the employment base of the Australian Capital Territory. I believe that the tourist industry is our major industry.
